title: Your Customers Hate MVPs. Make an SLC Instead.
image_desc: A graphic with the title "Your Customers Hate MVPs. Make an SLC Instead."  Perhaps a stylized image contrasting a frustrated customer with a happy one.
narration: Let's talk about Minimum Viable Products, or MVPs.  You might think they're the key to success, but the truth is, your customers probably hate them.  There's a better way:  Simple, Lovable, and Complete, or SLC.

title: The Problem with MVPs
content:
Customers see unfinished products.
MVPs often lack key features.
It's a selfish approach focusing on speed over customer satisfaction.
image_desc: An image depicting a frustrated customer looking at a poorly designed, incomplete app on their phone.
narration: MVPs prioritize speed and minimal development.  While this might seem efficient, the result is often an unfinished product that frustrates customers.  They see a lack of features and a half-baked experience, leading to dissatisfaction.

title: The SLC Approach: Simple, Lovable, Complete
content:
**Simple**
Small, quick to build.
Easy for customers to understand and use.
Focuses on core functionality.
**Lovable & Complete**
Delightful user experience.
Meets customer needs fully within its defined scope.
Customers genuinely want to use it.
image_desc: A split image showing a clean, intuitive app interface on one side and a cluttered, confusing interface on the other.
narration: SLC flips the script.  It's about building something simple, yet complete within its scope.  It's about creating a product customers love to use, not just a functional minimum.  Think Google Docs in its early days – simple, but complete for its core purpose.

title: Examples of Successful SLCs
content: (No additional content needed for this slide type)
image_desc: A collage of logos for successful products that started simple, like WhatsApp, Twitter, and Snapchat.
narration: Many hugely successful products started as SLCs. WhatsApp, Twitter, Snapchat – they all began with a core set of features that were simple, lovable, and complete.  They focused on delivering value from day one.

title: Breaking Maslow's Product Hierarchy
content:
Traditional thinking prioritizes usefulness first.
SLC prioritizes delight and then adds usefulness.
image_desc: A graphic showing Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs adapted for product development, highlighting the difference between the traditional approach and the SLC approach.
narration: The traditional approach to product development often prioritizes usefulness above all else.  SLC challenges this.  It prioritizes delight and customer love, building a product people want to use, even if it initially has a limited scope.

title: Life After SLC
content:
SLC products don't require constant development.
You have options: evolve or maintain.
Happy customers provide valuable feedback for future iterations.
image_desc: An image showing a product roadmap with multiple potential paths, emphasizing flexibility and choice.
narration: An SLC provides flexibility.  You can choose to evolve it, adding features based on customer feedback, or maintain it as a successful, simple product.  Either way, you've already delivered value and built a strong foundation.

title: Prioritize Your Customers
content: (No additional content needed for this slide type)
image_desc: An image of happy customers interacting positively with a product.
narration: SLC is about prioritizing the customer – the human being, not just their needs.  By building a lovable and complete product, you create a positive experience and build lasting customer relationships.

title: Conclusion: Choose SLC
content:
Customers prefer complete, lovable products.
SLC offers flexibility and better long-term outcomes.
Ask your customers – they'll agree!
